discussion.content: NVMe (Non-Volatile Memory Express) is a communications interface and driver that defines a command set and feature set for PCIe-based SSDs with the goals of increased and efficient performance and interoperability on a broad range of enterprise and client systems.

comments.content: To be clear, it was MicroSD. Cheers.

I agree NVMe is the correct answer
 because MicroSSD is for regular usage (5600 rpm) and 15000 rpm drives are used for gamming and SCSI systems.

questions.question_text:
A technician is configuring a high-performance workstation. The technician needs to choose storage for the boot drive with the highest performance possible.
Which of the following drive types BEST meets this requirement?

comments.content: Exactly what we do at work too. I've reimaged hundreds of lenovo 400s series and those are the settings i always change.

end user reported trying to improve the computerג€™s speed by changing some BIOS configurations randomly - is the key for this question and yes you are right B is the correct answer.

Because PXE server sends an OS image to client and if client changed secure boot to off then yes he would have the difficulty booting a device.

I agree.

I think the only reason the "failed to connect to PXE server" message was display is that it's one of the BIOS settings the user randomly adjusted.

discussion.content: We use PXE for imaging at work. If we are having an issue with it, the first thing we do is check and make sure that Secure Boot is enabled and Legacy Boot is disabled. So, I would go with "B" on this question.

STOP WITH THE BS and overthinking. He could not connect to the PXE server because someone messed with the settings. The first thing to check is if the address is correct because it failed to connect. IF it WAS CORRECT, then you can proceed to check other things/theories. STOP MAKING THIS this more complicated than it needs to be.

D is the correct, We use PXE for imaging at work. If we are having an issue with it, the first thing we do is check and make sure that Secure Boot is enabled and Legacy Boot is disabled. So, I would go with "B" on this question.

Selected Answer: B
We use PXE for imaging at work. If we are having an issue with it, the first thing we do is check and make sure that Secure Boot is enabled and Legacy Boot is disabled. So, I would go with "B" on this question.

The question text only talks about a local W10 operating system on a notebook that does not load. That there is a PXE server in the company is not mentioned. For me, 2 questions arise here. Has the user disabled Secure Boot or has he entered a PXE server address although there is no PXE server. Since I do not know, here is my question. What is asked first when booting, secure boot status or the PXE setting? Here it is asked which action should be done FIRST.

Selected Answer: B
Secure boot is your best bet.

All four are wrong, cause the end user messed up the cmos settings changing randomly. So the FIRST thing to do is WITHOUT A SINGLE DOUBT reset the cmos to default. THEN returning to the boot problem he should set the pxe server address

Read carefully, it's a /local/ Windows 10 boot, not server-based, so why would setting a PXE address fix the issue with booting the locally installed OS? 
Secure Boot should be correct.

hey guys, If secure boot is disabled, the machine will not load the OS. user needs to enable secure boot so that the OS will Load. The real issue the OS not loading. not this so called PXE server. Answer is B.

I believe the answer is B, you would need to ensure that Secure Boot is enable is the Admin is trying to do a PXE Boot to load the OS. Also the 2nd to last sentence can basically be taken out, has nothing to do with the issue.
The message on the screen shows a failed attempt to connect to a PXE server. it has to be D

comments.content:
I have never once seen a BIOS where you can actually set a PXE server address. This cannot be the correct answer. 
Secure Boot is a part of UEFI and is the only one that makes any sense here.
To be honest though, none of these answers are strictly correct.
This, you don't usually set the PXE address. IF you boot into PXE it sends out a message looking for PXE servers on the network

discussion.content: D or B ?
Correct Answer is B or C ? Pls. update...

comments.content:
"The answer should be re-enable UEFI mode"
Exactly! 
In some BIOS menu "UEFI mode" named "Secure Boot". 
So, i think right answer should be "B. Secure Boot should be enabled"

discussion.content: The answer should be re-enable UEFI mode. However, it is not an option! The systems were installed to HDDD. PXE is only for booting network images. It states the user changed settings, prior to the non-boot issue!

comments.content: But unchecking Wake-on-LAN only stops the computer from being turned on remotely. I think the question was worded poorly.

discussion.content: on BIOS, the PXE server setting can only be Enabled/disabled. don't see any place for PXE server address, so I'd ride with C on this one.

comments.content: PXE was mentioned, so just assume it has something to do with PXE. As confusing as that may seem.

discussion.content: Are you sure it's not C?

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is troubleshooting a notebook that is not loading the local Windows 10 operating system. All the computers inside the company are installed using UEFI mode selected. The message on the screen shows a failed attempt to connect to a PXE server. When requested, the end user reported trying to improve the computer's speed by changing some BIOS configurations randomly. Which of the following should the network administrator check FIRST inside
BIOS?

choices.D: The PXE server address should be set

questions.question_text: A customer recently moved a high-end graphics card from a known-working computer to a different computer. The computer works without issue when viewing email and web pages or when using certain applications. However, when a game with high-end graphics requirements is opened, the program will run for a few minutes before the computer shuts down. Which of the following is MOST likely causing the problem?

discussion.content: i've had this issue before where my pc would shutdown if the GPU did anything exciting for a period of time , changing power supplies fixed it.
why not video RAM? insufficient ram could cause to shut down

comments.content:
If you are using the latest graphics card but have an older and dated PSU, this could cause power fluctuation. As a user stated on the website Tom's Hardware, "Shutting off during games is 70% of the time a faulty power supply". : 
https://forums.tomshardware.com/threads/could-bad-ram-cause-a-computer-to-shut-down-in-the-middle-of-a-game.2531537/

If there was an insufficient ram I suppose you will get a BSOD but often windows will give you a warning "Your Computer Is Low On Memory" and you will experience a lot of performance issues.

The GPU should be providing the computers Video RAM. The OS can probably allocate extra VRAM to make up for any slack of deficit, but the GPU ought to have enough to perform its rated tasks.
I'm almost surprised that the computer is running for so long before it shuts down. I'd expect it to hit a wall as soon as the wattage draw is greater than the supply can provide.

discussion.content: So I know that A would be the best way to make the network secure, but D is the more reasonable ask wouldn't it be? In these questions should we assume that the people we are dealing with have a good understanding of technology? Like I wouldn't try to explain Mac Filtering to my grandparents, but I probably could guide them through changing a password.

From my network engineer buddy “ Personally, I could get into a network with “strong encryption” much faster than Mac filtering, secure=easy”. Yes you can spoof a MAC address but it’s still not easy”. Security and easy do not go hand and hand. 

“ So like, Imagine having two state of the art locks vs the biggest guy you’ve ever seen with a list of names.. which one do you think is easier to get into?”
Why not "Upgrade the encryption standards" and set a password?

questions.question_text:
An ISP has notified a SOHO user of a usage increase on the user's network. The user is concerned the WiFi network is being utilized by unauthorized users.
Which of the following would minimize the unauthorized use of the WiFi network?

discussion.content: (Universal Naming Convention) A standard for identifying servers, printers and other resources in a network, which originated in the Unix community. A UNC path uses double slashes or backslashes to precede the name of the computer

questions.question_text: Which of the following services provides the ability to resolve UNC to appropriate IP addresses?
